_link.title: I can draw a circuit diagram for a simple household electrical system

toLevel2.question: What is the first component electricity passes through when entering a household?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The meter measures total energy consumption before electricity reaches the switchboard.

distractors.answer: The circuit breakers
distractors.explanation: Circuit breakers are in the switchboard, after the meter.

distractors.answer: The power outlets
distractors.explanation: Outlets are end points; electricity passes through meter and switchboard first.

distractors.answer: The light switches
distractors.explanation: Switches control individual circuits; electricity enters via the meter.

toLevel2.question: What component allows all electricity to a house to be disconnected at once?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The main switch is in series before all circuits, allowing complete disconnection.

distractors.answer: Any power outlet
distractors.explanation: Outlets control individual appliances, not the whole house.

distractors.answer: The electricity meter
distractors.explanation: The meter measures consumption; the main switch disconnects power.

distractors.answer: Individual light switches
distractors.explanation: Light switches control single lights, not the entire house.

toLevel2.question: How are loads (appliances and lights) connected in a household circuit diagram?
toLevel2.correct: In parallel across active and neutral
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Parallel connection ensures each load receives full voltage and operates independently.

distractors.answer: In series along the active wire only
distractors.explanation: Series would cause voltage sharing; parallel is used for independence.

distractors.answer: Connected only to the earth wire
distractors.explanation: Earth is for safety; loads connect between active and neutral.

distractors.answer: In a ring formation around the house
distractors.explanation: While ring circuits exist, basic diagrams show parallel branches.

toLevel2.question: What component protects each individual circuit from overcurrent?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Each circuit has its own breaker that trips if current exceeds its rating.

distractors.answer: The main switch
distractors.explanation: The main switch disconnects everything; breakers protect individual circuits.

distractors.answer: The electricity meter
distractors.explanation: The meter measures usage; it doesn't protect circuits.

distractors.answer: The power outlet
distractors.explanation: Outlets are connection points; breakers provide protection.

toLevel2.question: In a circuit diagram, what do the three wires (active, neutral, earth) connect to?
toLevel2.correct: Active and neutral carry current; earth provides safety path
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Active and neutral form the circuit; earth connects exposed metal for fault protection.

distractors.answer: All three wires carry equal amounts of current
distractors.explanation: Earth normally carries no current; only active and neutral carry load current.

distractors.answer: Active carries current out, earth returns it
distractors.explanation: Neutral returns current; earth is for safety only.

distractors.answer: Neutral and earth are decorative and unused
distractors.explanation: Both are essential: neutral completes circuit, earth provides safety.

toLevel2.question: In a household circuit diagram, the meter comes before the main switch.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Electricity flows: meter (measuring) → main switch → circuit breakers → loads.

toLevel2.correctExplanation: Appliances are connected in parallel so each receives full voltage and operates independently.

toLevel3.question: Why are separate circuit breakers used for lighting and power outlet circuits?
toLevel3.correct: To allow independent protection and isolation of different circuit types
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Separate breakers mean a fault in one circuit doesn't affect others.

distractors.answer: Because lights and outlets use different voltages
distractors.explanation: Both use 230 V; separation is for protection and load management.

distractors.answer: To reduce the total wiring needed in the house
distractors.explanation: Separate circuits use more wiring; the benefit is protection.

distractors.answer: Because circuit breakers can only handle one appliance type
distractors.explanation: Breakers handle any load; separation is for practical protection.

toLevel3.question: In a household circuit diagram, where is the earth wire connected?
toLevel3.correct: To exposed metal parts of appliances and the main earth stake
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Earth provides a low-resistance path to ground for fault currents.

distractors.answer: Between active and neutral to complete the circuit
distractors.explanation: Active and neutral complete the circuit; earth is for safety.

distractors.answer: Only to the electricity meter for measurement
distractors.explanation: Earth is throughout the house for safety, not just at the meter.

distractors.answer: To the neutral wire at each outlet
distractors.explanation: Earth and neutral are separate in Australia; they connect at one point only.

toLevel3.question: What does a circuit diagram show that a pictorial diagram doesn't?
toLevel3.correct: The electrical connections using standardised symbols
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Circuit diagrams use symbols to clearly show electrical relationships.

distractors.answer: The physical location of components in the house
distractors.explanation: Pictorial diagrams show location; circuit diagrams show connections.

distractors.answer: The colours of wires used in the installation
distractors.explanation: Circuit diagrams focus on connections, not physical wire colours.

distractors.answer: The brand names of electrical equipment used
distractors.explanation: Circuit diagrams show connections, not equipment brands.

toLevel3.question: Looking at a circuit diagram, how can you identify that circuits are in parallel?
toLevel3.correct: Multiple branches connect between the same two points (active and neutral)
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Parallel branches share common connection points at each end.

distractors.answer: All components are drawn in a single straight line
distractors.explanation: A straight line suggests series; parallel has multiple branches.

distractors.answer: There are no switches shown in the diagram
distractors.explanation: Switches can exist in both series and parallel arrangements.

distractors.answer: The diagram only shows one component
distractors.explanation: Single components don't demonstrate parallel connection.

toLevel3.question: Why is the main switch positioned before the circuit breakers in the diagram?
toLevel3.correct: So it can disconnect all circuits simultaneously for safety
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The main switch upstream of breakers provides whole-house isolation.

distractors.answer: To increase the current carrying capacity
distractors.explanation: Position doesn't affect capacity; it affects isolation capability.

distractors.answer: Because breakers cannot be turned off manually
distractors.explanation: Breakers can be manually switched; main switch provides master control.

distractors.answer: To reduce voltage drop in the wiring
distractors.explanation: Main switch position is for safety control, not voltage regulation.

toLevel3.question: In converting a pictorial house wiring layout to a circuit diagram, what changes?
toLevel3.correct: Physical positions become electrical connections using symbols
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Circuit diagrams emphasise electrical relationships, not physical layout.

distractors.answer: The number of wires in the circuit increases
distractors.explanation: Wire count stays the same; representation style changes.

distractors.answer: The voltage of the system changes to DC
distractors.explanation: Voltage and AC nature don't change; only diagram style does.

distractors.answer: Components must be removed for simplification
distractors.explanation: All components appear; their representation becomes symbolic.
